https://x.com/Miramoonaz/status/1965996660452110725
Thanks Sir. Would probably help if the Wildcat team asks some influencers to provide more context to this situation if they canâ€™t do it themselves.

Don't know if I'd categorize that as misleading myself, as they're just sharing the specific "how" from Kinto their side (which I think is a huge mistake by Kinto, but that's a different discussion) - but I see that without having deep enough context on the actual platform, you could confuse it with "this is the only way Kinto could've handled the default" which is most definitely not the case.

Wildcat itself is neutral as a platform, in the sense that they don't (and shouldn't, from a legal perspective) advise users on how to use the tooling they create.
Without any mention of other options available such as the ones that you outlined here.

Thatâ€™s good to hear that itâ€™s not meant to be handled that way. 
A bit misleading though since the thread about this payback mechanism was posted by the official Wildcat account.
Nobody was talking about counterparty risk here. The discussion is about Wildcat not having a separate mechanism for default situations.

If you feel this way dump it already

Wildcat does not pool funds or force you to extend credit to any borrower. Itâ€™s purely infrastructure for borrowing and lending. If you choose to engage with a borrower as a lender, thatâ€™s entirely at your discretion, and honestly thatâ€™s how it should be. No pooled funds, no curators (they do still whitelist borrowers but afaik itâ€™s mostly to avoid NK & impersonations)
My take: https://x.com/stan3web/status/1964827103276253352?s=46

Agreed. if you are not willing to put in the work to do due diligence as a lender, then you should not get involved in extending credit. I do think that Wildcat, or any other uncollateralized lending protocol, is not a product people should flock to just to earn yield and assume itâ€™s passive, given the risks. However, for those willing to take on the risk and do the due diligence, it can be a fine product for extending credit.
To even ignore the potential existence of an MLA on the vault itself - which I'm not sure of was there or not. If so, that MLA underlines the actual rules of that vaults' participation.

not at all?

it does what it says on the tin. Defaulting is a very special case in terms of overall protocol design, and in that case its up to the defaulter to choose (together with hopefully a legal advisor on their end) how to proceed (if there are any proceeds to begin with, which gladfully is the case for Kinto). 

They're not required to utilize Wildcat to pay back lenders, as they defaulted as a company and are now just sharing leftovers. There's nothing that "locks them into" Wildcat to return these funds, and it's much much easier (*and probably also advisable if you speak to any actual lawyer) to NOT use Wildcat to pay back remaining proceeds.
